Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Benjamin Schweinhart is "Statistical Topology of Complex Systems, and Applications." The host institution for the fellowship is Ohio State University, and the sponsoring scientist is Matthew Kahle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI pursued research in topological and geometric data analysis and stochastic topology during the MSPRF fellowship. This research covered theory, methodology, and practice, and resulted in four publications, appearing in mathematics and physics journals including Advances in Mathematics and Physical Review E.


A major topic of the PI's research was the relationship between fractal dimension and persistent homology. Fractal dimension measures how the properties of a shape depend on the scale at which they are measured, and has a wide range of applications in fields ranging from materials science to biology to pure mathematics. Previous studies proposed estimators of fractal dimension defined in terms of persistent homology, and provided empirical evidence that those quantities agreed with classical notions of fractal dimension. The PI proved the first rigorous results towards this end, showing the dimension of a metric space can be recovered from the persistent homology of point samples.1,2 He also performed computational studies in collobaration with Jonathan Jaquette, which found that  a persistent homology-based dimension estimation algorithm performs as well or better than classical techniques in practice .3

 

The second major topic of the PI's research was the development of computational practicable methodologies to quantify the local structure of cell complexes and graphs. Many physical and biological processes give rise to structures with natural descriptions as cell complexes. These include atomic bond networks and vascular networks (which are one-dimensional cell complexes, or graphs) and polycrystalline materials and biological tissues (which are

three-dimensional cell complexes). In joint work with Jeremy Mason and David Rodney, the PI published a paper describing the local structure of silica glasses in terms of probability distributions of local configurations, in some sense generalizing the crystallographic notion of a single unit cell repeated throughout the material. This methodology was applied to differentiate molecular dynamics simulations of glasses produced at different cooling rates, and identify local environments associated with different preparations.4

 

The PI is continuing work on several other projects he began during the fellowship including (i)  the development of methodology to compare the grain structure of polycrystalline materials, (ii) computational estimation of configurational entropy, and (iii) higher-dimensional percolation models.

 

During the fellowship, the PI promoted interdisciplinary applications of topology and geometry by developing and releasing two software packages and attending several international conferences, including some attended by a mix of mathematicians, physicists, and materials scientists. He also mentored an undergraduate student on a research project on configurational entropy of point clouds, who is now pursuing a PhD in applied mathematics.


References:

  1. B. Schweinhart, Persistent Homology and the Upper Box Dimension, Discrete and Computational Geometry (2019). arXiv:1802.00533.
  2. B. Schweinhart, Fractal Dimension and the Persistent Homology of Random Geometric Complexes, Advances in Mathematics 372 (2020). arXiv:1808.02196
  3. J. Jaquette and B. Schweinhart, Fractal Dimension Estimation with Persistent Homology: A Comparative Study, Communications in Nonlinear Science and Numerical Simulation 84 (2020). arXiv:1907.11182.
  4. B. Schweinhart, D. Rodney, and J. K. Mason, Statistical Topology of Bond Networks with Applications to Silica, Physical Review E  101 (2020) arXiv:1910.05842.
